title: 7-zip
content:
• 7-Zip is an open-source file compression utility, with multiple platforms supported, including Windows, various Linux versions (Debian, Ubuntu, Fedora, etc), Mac OS X, BeOS, DOS, and so on.
  • Similar in concept to PKZip, it also supports the very widely used Zip format. But it also has its own format (7z) which allows greater compression than Zip
  • For encryption, the 7z format allows the user to encrypt with military-grade AES256 (there is actually no other option), and the filenames themselves can also be encrypted, a capability that normal Zip lacks.

title: A user complains that after repeated attempts at logging onto his domain acccount, he continues to receive the message that username/password is incorrect. (Domain Account Issues)
content: User could be logging onto his computer and not the actual domain.

title: Active Directory (AD) Protocol
content: Microsoft's LDAP server implementation. Netscape, Sun, Novell, IBM, OpenLDAP, and Microsoft developed LDAP-based directory servers

title: Active Directory Group Policy Hierarchy
content:
In AD, group policies are processed according to hierarchy (LSDOU)
L - Local Policy: FIRST policy that it processes, every higher policy override settings at this level.
S - Site Policy: Less often used. To group settings by location (e.g. SG, Europe, etc.)
D - Domain Policy: To deploy GPOs to all users/computers of a domain.
OU - Organizational Unit: FINAL policy processed. OVERRIDES all other lower settings. Linking to an OU is preferred method to deploy GPOs. Different OUs can be created for different teams/departments.

title: As part of service hardening measures, which of the following alternative options CANNOT be used in place of LSA?
content: Windows Service Account

title: Basic NTFS permissions
content: Full Control, Modify, Read & execute, Read, Write, Special permissions

title: BitLocker
content:
BitLocker is Microsoft's implementation of volume encryption including FDE (Full Disk Encryption)
Can be used to encrypt specific partitions or the entire drive including system partition
Includes built-in support for TPM (Trusted Platform Module) chip found on some higher-end laptops.
Microsoft offers multiple ways to configure access to an encrypted BitLocker volume:
  • TPM only
  • TPM + PIN
  • TPM + PIN + USB Key
  • TPM + USB Key
  • USB Key
  • Password only
Compared to EFS, BitLocker is available only on even higher-end and relatively more recent Windows editions for business use, and Windows Server editions from 2008 onward.

title: Bootloaders & Security Concerns With Bootloaders
content:
The Bootloader is the first code to get executed in order to load an operating system.

Infected malware can alter the bootloader so that it can get something loaded into the Windows kernel is called a bootkit.

Bootkits
  • Viruses spread via thumbdrives, exploits and other more advanced ways
  • Has the potential to disable your anti-virus software before it evens gets a chance to start.


Ransomware moves the original MBR to a different location and places itself at the beginning of the drive.

Ransomware code:
  • Is the first code that runs when the BIOS switches to the drive, to carry on the boot of the system.
  • Symptom of affected system is a ransomware displays a message telling you where and how to buy a password using bitcoin or your files are encrypted. Once you pay, your files or system MAY/MAY NOT be restored.

title: Central Processing Unit (CPU)
content:
Central Processing Unit (CPU) consists of 3 basic components:
  • CPU Register - A special, high-speed storage area within the CPU, holds instructions, storage address, or any kind of data.
  • Arithmetic-logic unit (ALU) - Does artithmetic and logical operations.
  • Control Unit - Tells the ALU what operation to perform on the data found in the input register, as well as to store the computed result in an output register. Moves the data between input, output register, ALU, and memory

title: Check-Rectify-Confirm
content:
Check - Check that the setting is set to the correct option.
Rectify - Change the setting or policy if it is wrong.
Confirm - Confirm that the setting/policty has been correctly set.

title: CIA model
content:
Emphasizes the Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability of IT resources and assets.
Confidentiality: Kept private or secret. Allow what needs to be known to be seen or used by only those who need to know.
Integrity: Protecting data from modification or deletion. Erroneous changes made by authorized people can be undone.
Availability: Data must be available for use when needed. Prevent Website defacement so data is available to the public

title: Clock Speed
content:
Also referred as clock rate, CPU frequency.

More on frequency:
  • Frequency is the number of occurrences of a repeating cycle per unit time
  • Frequency is measured in Hertz(Hz)
  • The repeating event is known as a period

Analogy: If a computer is a car, then the CPU is the engine. The higher the clock speed, the faster the car will be.

title: Cloud Computing
content:
• Cloud computing refers to a network of remote servers hosted on the Internet to store, manage, and process data, rather than a local server or a personal computer. Virtualization is the fundamental technology that powers cloud computing.
  • Virtualization means "to create a virtual version of a device or resource," however many computing devices and technologies can be virtualized, including a server, desktop, storage, network, or even an operating system.

Advantages:
  • Effective Resource Usage - CPU/RAM/DISK can be allocated whenever needed.
  • Ease of Management - Unused VMs can be turned off until required.
  • Security - Separate VM servers do not pose a risk to each other, Test out applications if you are not sure of its source, Test out your software on the VMs

title: CPU Cache
content:
• CPU Cache is a small and fast memory used by CPU to reduce time to access data from the main memory, another name for main memory is Random-Access Memory (RAM). It stores copies of frequently used data.
  • When processor needs data, it first checks whether a copy of that data is in the cache (faster to get from cache than RAM)
  • L1, L2 cache owned by each core, L3 cache shared by all cores
  • A large cache can increase computer performance in general but there are other considerations: read latency (time to search for content), cache coherency (consistency in content between RAM and cache)

title: CPU Speed Calculation
content:
• CPU Speed is the number of calculations/ instructions it can process in one second (depends on clock speed and cores and cache).
  • For example, a dual core 3.0 GHz processor would be capable of running faster than a single core 3.0 GHz processor. Although both have the same clock speed, but the dual core processor can perform more calculations as it has two cores.

Calculation Example

title: Data at Rest Meaning
content: Data that is being stored in a storage medium. E.g., employee records in database tables, Office documents (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) on a company server.

title: Data at Rest Security Risks
content: Lost / stolen / leaked devices with confidential data, data corruption from human error / unauthorized changes / hardware failure.

title: Data at Rest Solutions
content:
Backups and Disaster Recovery (DR), protect against hardware failures and data corruption but not data leaks.
File and folder encryption / Volume encryption

title: Data in Motion Meaning
content: Data being sent over a communication channel. E.g., web pages sent to browsers, files copied to/from network shared folders.

title: Data in Motion Security Risks
content: Man-in-the-middle attacks, data intercepted/modified in transit.

title: Data in Motion Solutions
content: Ensure HTTPS connections (i.e., SSL certificates on servers), Use VPNs, Use secure file transfer (SFTP, FTPS, SCP, etc.) instead of FTP, Using SSH instead of Telnet.`

title: Difference between net and sc Windows commands
content:
The "net" command is limited to "net start" and "net stop".
It uses synchronous mode, which waits for the operation to complete before returning control to the user.

"sc" command runs in asynchronous mode, which means control is returned to the user even before operation completes.

title: Disk Partition
content:
Divides a storage device into multiple logical storage units (partitions) with dedicated area for paging/swapping and dedicated area for cache & log files. In a typical disk partition setup, a system partition is allocated for the OS, and a data partition is allocated for storing user data.
REDIRECT:Disk Partitioning Schemes for types of partitions.

title: Disk Partition Schemes
content: Master Boot Record (MBR) - Max partition size of 2 TB, max of 4 primary partitions, or 3 primary partitions + one extended partition. GUID Partition Table (GPT) - Max partition size of 8 ZB (Zettabytes), max no. of partitions limited by OS (Windows limit is 128), need 64-bit hardware and OS.

title: Domain Controller (DC) Refresh Policy
content: REDIRECT:Policy Refresh

title: Domain Service Account
content: REDIRECT:Service Hardening Methods / LSA Alternatives

title: EFS (Encrypting File System)
content:
• Introduced since Windows 2000
  • Provides user-transparent, filesystem-level encryption
  • EFS encryption can be carried out by file, folder, or drive
  • EFS can only be enabled on NTFS-formatted drives and on specific Windows editions

  • EFS uses a mixture of symmetric and asymmetric cryptography
  • Plaintext file is encrypted using a symmetric FEK (File Encryption Key) for better performance
  • User's public key is used to encrypt FEK, which goes into DDF section
  • Recovery agent's public key is used to encrypt FEK, which goes into DRF section
  • User's private key is encrypted with a hash of the user's NTLM password hash plus username

title: Enterprise Patch Management
content: Enterprise Patch Management is the process of identifying, acquiring, verifying, and testing, and installing patches for products and systems within an organization.

title: File System Types
content: REDIRECT:Types of File Systems

title: Functions of a File System
content: Control how data is stored and retrieved, provided access control (e.g., read/write permissions), provide metadata (e.g., file creation time, time it was last accessed)

title: Hardware Requirement
content:
Specifications of hardware compatible with the required software.
Choice of hardware components:
  • CPU (e.g. Quad core Intel)
  • Random Access Memory (RAM) (e.g. 6 GB)
  • Graphics Card (e.g. Nvidia GeForce 660)

title: Internet Explorer Enhanced Security Configuration (IE-ESC)
content: Adjusts IE extensibility & security settings to reduce IT security threats, reduces the functionality of webpages, web-based applications, local network resources, & applications on browsers.

title: Latency & Throughput
content:
• Latency - Time taken for data to go from source to destination. Delay can be caused by:
    • distance
    • congestion
    • transmission errors and error recovery
    • processing capabilities of systems involved in the transmission
  • Throughput - Number of bits successfully transmitted per second
    • measured in bits per second
    • actual (measured) throughput is always less than the theoretical maximum throughput

title: List of Proprietary / Open-source Software
content:
Proprietary
  • Adobe products (Photoshop, Premiere Pro, etc.)
  • Microsoft Windows
  • Microsoft Office (PowerPoint, Word, Excel, etc.)
  • MacOS
Non-Proprietary (Open-source)
  • GNU Image Manipulation Program (Gimp)
  • Linux

title: Local System Account (LSA)
content:
Services default to log on as the LSA, which is against Principle of Least Priviledge (POLP). LSA gives the service almost unlimited privileges on Windows, like UNIX root account.

Running a service as LSA gives the service unlimited priviledges on a Windows system, similar to UNIX root account. If a malicious service is installed on a Windows system, it can do a lot of damage to the system if it runs on LSA.

If an attacker exploits a vulnerability of a service running as an LSA, they can do almost anything to the computer, such as modifying the AD database, install/remove programs, etc.

title: Managed Service Account
content: REDIRECT:Service Hardening Methods / LSA Alternatives

title: Mandatory Access Control (MAC)
content:
• Every resource assigned a classification (security) label
    Example: Top Secret > Secret > Confidential > Restricted > Unclassified
  • Each resource is assigned a classification and each user, a clearance level
  • User's clearance checked by OS or security kernel to determine access level.
  • MAC criteria are defined by administrators n strictly enforced by the OS or security kernel and, cannot be altered by end users
Disadvantages of using MAC model:
  • Rigid and inflexible, limited/no scope for user control
  • Administrative overhead (setting classifications, clearing personnel)
  • Requires constant monitoring to keep resource and user classifications up to date
Advantages of using MAC model:
  • Centralized control with well-defined structures and protocols
  • Very secure
  • Easy to scale to large organizations (entire armed forces, entire government)

title: Master Boot Partitioning Max Size
content: 2 TB

title: Maximum size of Single File on NTFS
content: 16 TB

title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday
content: Regular patches from Microsoft on the second Tuesday of each month. Worldwide roll-out from Tue 10:00am PST (but not sent out all at once to every computer in the world. Will take a few hours for updates to roll out across the world)

title: Multi-Homed Network
content: Connect network to multiple ISPs. (Firewall / Router / Proxy Server)

title: net command
content: Only has "net start" and "net stop" commands. Usage: net start/stop "<service name>" (e.g. net start "FileZilla Server") Netstat commands use synchronous mode, which waits for operation to complete before returning control to user.

title: New Technology File System (NTFS) Permissions
content:
Based on Discretionary Access Control (DAC) model, the owner of the file decides who can access it

Basic NTFS permissions:
Full controlModifyRead & executeReadList folder contentsWrite

Advanced NTFS permissions:
Full controlTraverse folder/Execute fileRead permissionsWrite attributes
Read attributesList folder/Read dataWrite extended attributesTake ownership
DeleteDelete subfolders and filesCreate files/Write dataChange permissions
Create folders/Append dataRead extended Attributes

title: Pagefile.sys in Windows
content:
• Pagefile.sys is used when there is insufficient RAM to run a program, Windows moves data from RAM to a page file to free RAM
  • Windows memory manager is always using pagefile.sys, hence it cannot be deleted unless the page file feature is disabled
  • pagefile.sys defaults:
    • In root folder on same drive as Windows system files (e.g. C:\)
    • Size changes and depends on how much RAM installed
      • Minimum - 1.5 x RAM for RAM <1GB, 1 x RAM otherwise
      • Maximum - 3 x RAM

title: Paging
content:
For Paging Terminology, see Which statement is true/false for paging?
Page fault - Page not found in RAM
Actions to be taken in a page fault:
  1. Find page on disk
  2. Find empty page frame in RAM
  3. Transfer page from disk to empty page frame
  4. Update page table
  5. Retry instruction which caused page fault, return control to running process

Replacement Policy takes place when deciding which page to be replaced when there is no free page frame. E.g. First In First Out (FIFO)

title: Policy Refresh
content:
Workstations, Member Servers: Every 90min, with a random offset interval up to 30 min.
Domain Controllers (DC): Every 5 min

title: Principle of Least Privilege (POLP)
content:
Minimal level of access that allows normal functioning. Give the lowest level of rights with which users can still do their jobs. Limits potential damage of security breach.
E.g., Staff from HR can only access HR data and not Admin data

title: Private IP Address Classes
content:
ClassPrivate Address Range
Class A0.0.0.0 to 126.255.255.255
Local Loopback Address127.0.0.0 to 127.255.255.255
Class B128.0.0.0 to 191.255.255.255
Class C192.0.0.0 to 223.255.255.255

title: Problems with Patches
content: The day after Patch Tuesday, hackers will swoop in with new zero-day exploits. Hackers can also reverse-engineer patches to create new exploits in a matter of days or even hours. Hackers also have an entire month between Patch Tuesdays to exploit the vulnerability.

title: Process States
content:
• Created / New: process created; automatically goes to waiting state for most desktop OSs
  • Ready / Waiting: process loaded into main memory and awaiting execution on CPU
  • Running: process executed by CPU
  • Terminated: process completed execution or explicitly killed
  • Blocked: process waits for currently unavailable resources or completion of an I/O operation
  • Swapped out and waiting: Process moved from main memory to virtual memory while in waiting state
  • Swapped out and blocked: Process moved from main memory to virtual memory while in blocked state

    • (Note: Swapped out will occur when there is not enough memory space to hold the process while in waiting/blocking state)

title: Reduce attack surface for Oracle Java JRE
content:
• The JDK package, meant for Java development and debugging, is not the main security issue
  • Standalone Java applications, mostly controlled and running on servers, is not the main security issue
  • The JRE package, with the auto-installed browser plugins, is the MAIN security issue
  • Solution: Disable "Enable Java content in the browser" setting

title: Role Based Access Control (RBAC)
content:
Regulates access to resources based on the role(s) of a user
Roles can be defined by competency, authority, or area of responsibility
Roles are easily changed or revoked without updating each user’s permissions
If a user switches to another role, his profile can be updated to the new role
Compares to ACL or DAC which grant/deny access on a per-object basis
Widely used in software (especially enterprise) and web applications

Disadvantages of using RBAC model
  • Role explosion - number of roles increases with complexity of security requirements
  • Role management - in complex RBAC systems, the result of applying roles, scopes and permissions may not be easy to determine
  • Tight coupling - RBAC is usually tightly coupled with an OS, application, or system

Advantages of using RBAC model
  • Ease of administration - easy to assign or revoke role to and from user, reduces cost
  • Broad adoption - easily implemented and widely understood; enterprise users use RBAC
  • Security principles - ensures SOD, applies POLP

title: sc command (Service Controller)
content: Usage: sc start/stop "<service name>" (e.g. sc start "FileZilla Server") sc commands use asynchronous mode, which does not wait for the operation to complete before returning control to the user. Could be more efficient if next operation does not depend on the service status.

title: Security Assesment with Belarc Advisor (BA)
content:
BA is a Windows tool to automate the Check portion of the check-rectify-confirm concept (introduced in L07). It's similar to Lynis which is for Linux.

BA provides information of missing Microsoft updates, AV status, and security benchmarks.

Runs on Windows 8, 10, Server 2012, 2016.

title: Security concern with Virtualization
content: Misconfigured VM due to necessary services are stopped.

title: Separation of Duties (SOD)
content:
Definition of SOD:
SOD is known as segregation of duties
Involves breaking down tasks and permissions of an individual into multiple tasks

Objectives of SOD:
To prevent conflict of interest, fraud, abuse, and errors
To ensure at least 2 individuals responsible for a task, restrict power held by one individual
To ensure individuals are not responsible for reporting on themselves

Example of SOD:
Software developers should not have access to production systems. Also, software developers and testers should be separate roles

Cost of SOD:
Additional costs due to head count increase, will also impact efficiency and complexity
Do risk assessment to determine if SOD is necessary, or other measures can be taken
Apply SOD only to the most vulnerable and mission-critical parts of the business

title: Service Administration
content: Use net and sc commands (see net command and sc command for more info)

title: Service Control Manager (SCM)
content: Service control programs communicate with the Service Control Manager (SCM), which is a special process that starts at sys boot. It starts, stops and interacts with Windows service processes. Located at C:\Windows\System32\services.exe

title: Service Control Manager (SCM) purposes
content: Maintains/locks/unlocks service database, tracks stats. of installed services, starts services/driver services on sys. startup/upon demand, transmit control requests to running services.

title: Service Hardening Methods / LSA Alternatives
content:
Local and Network Service
Microsoft has provided 2 additional SIDs for Local Administrators to assign to services:
  • Local Service (SID: S-1-5-19) - For services that only access local resources & don't need access to network resources. Actual name: NT AUTHORITY\LocalService.
  • Network Service (SID: S-1-5-20) - For services that need access to network resources, accesses network resources using the computer's credentials - similar to LSA. Actual name: NT AUTHORITY\NetworkService. Both Local Service and Network Service don't have a password like LSA.

Domain Service Account/Managed Service Account/Virtual Account
Besides Local and Network Service, Windows supports alternative approaches to assigning service accounts with restricted privileges.
  • Domain Service Account - Able to centrally manage as a domain account in AD, able to assign specific perms, needs manual/custom password management.
  • Managed Service Account - Needs Windows PowerShell to setup, no GUI support for creating and managing MSAs, password auto created for MSA when account is created, refreshed every 30 days. Password can also be changed manually.
  • Virtual Account - Need to use sc command to setup, virtual account name is NT SERVICE\, automatically generated 240-byte, random password, non-expiring account and cannot be locked out, service logs on as virtual account with same service name, makes auditing easier.

title: Service Identifiers (SID) - Common SIDs to know
content: Local System (SID:S-1-5-18) | Local Service (SID : S-1-5-19) | Network Service (SID : S-1-5-20)

title: Service Startup Options
content: Automatic: Service starts automatically as part of Windows boot process; Automatic (Delayed Start): Services starts automatically with a delay, to let other services with Automatic start execute first; Manual: Service is off by default but can be started by another app or process that needs it. Once started, will remain on until manually stopped or system reboots. Disabled: Service will not start and cannot be started unless setting is changed.

title: Service Testing
content: Unit testing > System Integration Testing (SIT) > On-Site Acceptance Testing (OSAT) > User Acceptance Testing (UAT)

title: Services (Characteristics)
content: Advanced feature of MS Windows (known earlier as NT services), support mgmnt of long running/background processes and applications (similar to UNIX daemons), can start before any user logs on, ideal for software that needs to start at machine boot (e.g. web/database/app servers), can continue running even after all users log off

title: Services (Purpose)
content: Provide core OS functions like event logging, file serving, printing, time synchronization, etc.

title: Single and Multi-core Processors
content:
Single-core processor performs one operation at a time, rapidly switching between different tasks, giving the illusion of doing many things concurrently

Multi-core processors have multiple CPUs on a single chip
  • Execute multiple operations at the same time
    Reduce waiting times and enhance the computer's productivity
  • Effect of multi-core only noticeable when multitasking (e.g. running many applications concurrently)
  • Share other components (e.g. RAM, can be a bottleneck when all processors need to read/write data at the same time), thus:

speed ≠ number of core * speed of one core

title: Software Requirement
content: Defines the software resource requirement and prerequisite needed in the computer system in order for the application to run properly.

title: System Requirement
content: An ideal set of guidelines for hardware/software requirement to run the application.

title: Throughput Formula
content:
• Throughput formula
    • For simplex or half-duplex communication channel:
      Data rate = clock speed * width
    • for full-duplex communication channel:
      Data rate = clock speed * width * 2
  • Width: Indicates how many bits the bus can transmit per cycle
  • Clock speed: Speed of the clock signal used for the bus
  • E.g. bus width = 32 bits, clock speed = 100MHz, transmission = full-duplex

title: Types of File Systems
content:
Windows: FAT (File Allocation Table) - FAT16/FAT32, exFAT (extended FAT), NTFS (New Technology File System), HFS (Hierarchical File System - can read but can't write)

List of File Systems and Maximum Filesizes
FAT typeMax filesMax file sizeMax volume size
FAT124,09632MB32MB
FAT1665,5362GB2GB
FAT32268,435,4564GB2TB
NTFS4,294,967,296256TB256TB

title: VeraCrypt
content:
• VeraCrypt is based on TrueCrypt, a widely used, open-source volume encryption software
  • In May 2014 , TrueCrypt's developers disappeared under mysterious circumstances
  • Mounir Idrassi, security developer from Paris, France, has been releasing VeraCrypt since Jun 2013 at https://veracrypt.codeplex.com
  • VeraCrypt supports multiple platforms, including (for system encryption) Windows XP to Windows 10, Windows Server 2003 to Windows Server 2012, (non-system encryption) Linux and Mac OS.
  • Unlike Microsoft's own EFS and BitLocker, there is no limitation on Windows editions where it can be used
  • VeraCrypt supports 3 main operation modes: encrypted file container, non-system partition/drive encryption, and also system partition/drive encryption which implements Full Disk Encryption (FDE)
  • An advanced, "Inception-style", hidden volume mode is also available, allowing users to hide an encrypted container within another encrypted container, allowing for "plausible deniability"
  • VeraCrypt supports multiple ciphers (AES, Serpent, Twofish and combinations thereof, 128-bit to 256-bit), and hashing algorithms (SHA512, SHA256, RIPEMD-160, Whirlpool)

title: Virtual Account

title: Web Server Role (IIS)
content: Is a web server to host anything on the internet, comes bundled with WSUS

content: Local Service Account (see Service Hardening Methods / LSA Alternatives) for more info.

title: Which of the following is FALSE about WSUS?
content: WSUS server-to-client communications should be set up to use HTTP. (HTTP is not a form of communication for WSUS server-client. The correct way is using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL))

content: Web Server Role (IIS)

title: Which of the following is NOT an acceptable step to secure an OS?
content: Enabling dual boot at BIOS setting.

title: Which of the following is NOT an example of a device that has multi-homed network?
content: Hub

content: Adobe Reader Updates (Provided: Microsoft Office Service packs, Microsoft Windows Service packs, Microsoft Windows Feature packs)

title: Which of the following is the cost of WSUS?
content: Free (WSUS comes free with Windows Server)

title: Which of the following types of VMware network connection should you choose if you want your WSUS server to be able to download patches from Windows Update?
content: REDIRECT:WSUS Server on Vmware

title: Which of the network modes should be used if you want to ensure that network connections that are initiated from the physical network cannot reach your VM even though your VM can access the physical network?
content: Network Address Translation (NAT)

title: Which statement is true/false for paging?
content:
True:
  • Page in means page is transferred from disk to RAM.
  • Page out means page is transferred from RAM to disk.
  • Page Fault = Page Miss.
  • Page Fault / Page Miss means the requested page is not in RAM.
  • Page Hit means the requested page is in RAM.

title: Windows Password Policy
content:
Enabling the password complexity setting requires each password to meet the following requirements:
  1. The password may not contain the account name or part of the full name (delimited by commas, periods, dashes or hyphens, underscores, spaces, pound signs, and tabs) that exceed two consecutive characters.

    Both checks are not case sensitive, e.g. a user with the name "Erin M. Hagens" cannot have a password that includes "erin" or "hagens".

  2. The password must contain characters from at least 3 out of the 5 categories:
    • Uppercase letters of European languages (for English, A to Z)
    • Lowercase letters of European languages (for English, a to z)
    • Numeric digits (0 to 9)
    • Special characters (for example: !, $, #, %)
    • Unicode characters not categorized as uppercase or lowercase alphabetic characters. This includes Unicode characters from Asian languages.

title: Windows Server Update Services (WSUS)
content:
A FREE patch management solution included in Windows Server, manages updates and security patches for Microsoft products, manage drivers, tools, service packs, and feature packs.

1 WSUS server need to be able to download updates from Windows Updates

Other WSUS server can get updates from the 1 connected WSUS or Windows Updates

WSUS server-to-server needs SSL, more secure than telnet

title: Windows Service Recovery Actions
content:
Automatic recovery actions can be specified if a service fails to start or if it crashes for some reason:
  • Take No Action
  • Restart the Service
  • Run a Program
  • Restart the Computer

title: Windows Services to Disable
content:
Windows Insider Service (wisvc). | Disable if not beta testing new versions of Windows via the Insider program.
SSDP Discovery (SSDPSRV)| UPnP functionality. Possible security risk.
Retail Demo Service (RetailDemo) | Not disabled by default? Really?
Remote Procedure Call (RPC) Locator (RpcLocator) | No function in Windows 10.
Internet Connection Sharing (ICS) (SharedAccess) | Old service no longer needed.
IIS Admin Service (IISADMIN) | Do not install.
Downloaded Maps Manager (MapsBroker) | I do not use Windows/Bing maps. Google for the win here.
Application Layer Gateway Service (ALG) | Old functionality no longer needed.
Bluetooth Support Service (bthserv) | Disable if no requirement for Bluetooth devices is desired.
Remote Desktop Services (TermService) | Potential security risk as attacker can gain remote desktop access to a device via a compromised system
Remote Registry (RemoteRegistry) | Potential security risk as attacker can gain remote access to a registry via a compromised system

title: Windows Workstation Refresh Policy
content: REDIRECT:Policy Refresh

title: WSUS Server on Vmware
content: NAT or Bridged (allows the VM to access the physical interface on the host, and therefore access the internet)

title: WSUS Set Up
content:
Synchronize with another upstream WSUS server at Port 8350 or with Microsoft Update
Download updates from downstream WSUS server if bandwidth limited + too many employees.
